jQuery

Intro To Jquery

JQuery

What is JQuery

jQuery is a fast, small, and feature-rich JavaScript library. It makes things like HTML document traversal and manipulation, event handling, animation, and Ajax much simpler with an easy-to-use API that works across a multitude of browsers.

jQuery makes it easier to do common tasks than writing ‘vanilla’ javascript.

How to add JQuery to your site

Add the script to the bottom of your html document, just before the closing body tag

<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/1.12.2/jquery.min.js"></script>

Then add the document ready function to your scripts.js file:

$(document).ready(function(){

   // jQuery methods go here...

});

This is to prevent any jQuery code from running before the document is finished loading (is ready).

It is good practice to wait for the document to be fully loaded and ready before working with it. This also allows you to have your JavaScript code before the body of your document, in the head section.

Here are some examples of actions that can fail if methods are run before the document is fully loaded like trying to hide an element that is not created yet, trying to get the size of an image that is not loaded yet.

Activities

First set up your html:

<div id="click-me"> CLICK ME </div>
<div id="sweet-box"> Awww Yea! </div>

and then your css:

div {
    padding: 2%;
    margin: 1%;
}

#click-me {
    border: 1px solid red;
}
#sweet-box {
    background-color: teal;
}

1. Click on an element and trigger an alert

Click on an element (that says click me) and get an alert

Events: Events are things that can happen when a user interacts with your page. For example, a user clicks on a div, or hovers over a div, or presses a key on their keyboard.

jQuery lets you write an “event listener” which will listen for those events. The “click” function is a jQuery function that will add an event listener for a click to the element it is used on.

In this example, click will add an event listener to the div with the id “click-me”.

$("#click-me").click(function() {
    alert("HEY BABE");
});

2. Toggle

make a red box underneath and give it an id of ‘sweet-box’, make it toggle (hide / show) every time you click on the button above

$("#click-me").click(function() {
  $("#sweet-box").toggle();
});

3. Change Class

when we click on the ‘click me’ change the class

$("#click-me").click(function() {
  $("#sweet-box").toggleClass("featured");
});

Then we need to add the class to the css:

.featured {
  background-color: orange;
}

4. Change Class of the element you clicked

when we click on the thing, using ‘this’ add a class to the element itself

$("#click-me").click(function() {
  $(this).addClass("bright");
});

.bright {
  background-color: yellow;
}

5. Fade Toggle

$("#click-me").click(function() {
  $("#sweet-box").fadeToggle();
});

6. Chaining

chaining (fade out, wait, fade back in)

$("#click-me").click(function() {
  $("#sweet-box").fadeOut().delay(3000).fadeIn();
});

7. On Hover

on hover — same thing

$("#click-me").hover( function() {
    $("#sweet-box").fadeOut().delay(3000).fadeIn();
});
